questions.neutral: Did you time it well - calm right now?

hobby.message: Political literature still keeping you up?
What's your last origami fold say?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Timed, perhaps. Not a fan of crowds these days.
I restore antique typewriters in my quiet hours.
Most wouldn’t see the appeal or the point. Suits me fine.
Recent disruptions haven’t helped maintenance routines.
Timing is everything now. Too much noise lately.
My hobby’s restoring old typewriters. Keeps the mind steady.
Used to borrow parts from others—now that’s… less reliable.
Compensation seekers keep turning up, interfering with the work.
I prefer being left to my repairs and my notes.
Quiet is rare these days. I use it to work on my typewriters.
Restoring antiques is my hobby. Old keys, the satisfaction of ribbon alignment.
Had a mishap thanks to a neighbor filing a compensation form.
She tapped away, smudged the platen. System chaos spills into everything lately.
Funny, even hobbies get swept up in these reforms.
Not many left who understand the difference between Olympia and Erika.
Yes, I watch for calmer hours just to return to my typewriters.
Restoration—mechanical, not digital. Each key springs back a century.
Last week, Elena, new on the registry, borrowed my Erica for forms.
More and more people want hard copies. Tribunal reparations, you see.
It’s odd—old machines feel suddenly important again. Like a peculiar currency.
I track precise dates for each repair. Even that raises system alerts now.
Sometimes, I miss when these things were overlooked. Noise, but harmless.
I time these visits for peace—reminds me of fixing typewriters late at night.
It’s what I do: antique typewriter restoration, real mechanics—each machine with its story.
After the reparations tribunal, neighbors started needing actual documents, not just data.
Just last week, my Erica produced formal copies for someone ‘reinstated’ after years erased.
Used to be a private ritual. Now I clean bureaucratic fingerprints from the keys.
I keep a handwritten log for each project—ironic, given the city’s surveillance zeal.
Last blackout, I restored an Olympia in candlelight. The city almost felt human.
Sometimes I wonder if these old keys remember what’s been silenced.
hobby_answer: Still keeping the collection, yes.
They don't make them like they used to.
Lately, too many people interested in paper records.
Tribunal's made things...unpredictable.
Hard to enjoy old habits these days.
Still have a few, yes. Mostly for my own notes.
Restoring an Erica, though supplies are harder to find now.
After that mural—more eyes on anything off-network.
Council bulletin shook up the block. Some old tenants reappeared.
Had a stranger ask to use my typewriter, said compensation forms needed it.
Not the kind of attention I want.
Yes, still collecting. Working on an old German Erica model now.
I like keeping my notes off the terminals.
After the tribunal statements, folks started showing up with Council paperwork.
One neighbor—gone for years—asked to use my typewriter for appeals.
I obliged, though it felt odd.
Feels like private hobbies are less private now.
Guess system changes ripple into every corner.
Still collecting, though these days it's more for the ritual than the function.
Restoration keeps my hands steady. I still type my journals.
Now, since the tribunal, everyone's chasing old records or forms.
Had someone return just to borrow my ribbon for compensation papers.
She hadn't touched a typewriter in years, but thought paper might reach them.
The BCI never tracked keystrokes, but now even ink attracts notice.
Hard not to feel exposed, even fixing small machines at home.
Strange how chaos can reach the quietest corners.
You know it, Alex. Still have seven in the flat—each with its own quirks.
I picked up the hobby years before the BCI. Paper felt honest.
These days, keeping one is almost subversive. More so after Halden's mural incident.
Since the tribunal, old neighbors have re-emerged looking for ways to leave a trace.
One borrowed my typewriter for Council compensation. Her hands shook harder than the carriage did.
Strange, seeing analog fear in digital times.
The BCI never knew how to read erasures or overwritten lines.
But now, with everyone scrambling for justice, even keys feel suspect.
I clean them out of habit, but some ink never fades from a system like this.
